greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least odd k such that k*2^n-1 is prime.
comment: If a(n)=1 then n is a Mersenne exponent (A000043). - _Pierre CAMI_, Apr 22 2013

Empirically, as N increases, (Sum_{n=1..N} a(n)) / (Sum_{n=1..N} n) tends to log(2); this is consistent with the prime number theorem as the probability that x*2^n - 1 is prime is ~ 1/(n*log(2)) if n is large enough.
link: Pierre CAMI, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000 (first 1000 terms from T. D. Noe)
Poo-Sung Park, Multiplicative functions with f(p + q - n_0) = f(p) + f(q) - f(n_0), arXiv:2002.09908 [math.NT], 2020.
formula: a(n) << 19^n by Xylouris' improvement to Linnik's theorem. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Dec 10 2013
Conjecture: a(n) = O(n log n). - _Thomas Ordowski_, Oct 15 2014
example: a(10)=5 because 5*2^10-1 is prime but 1*2^10-1 and 3*2^10-1 are not.
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{k = 1}, While[ !PrimeQ[k*2^n - 1], k += 2]; k]; Table[f@n, {n, 0, 80}] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Feb 20 2007 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(k=1); while(!isprime(k*2^n - 1), k+=2); k}; \\ _Indranil Ghosh_, Apr 03 2017
print([a(n) for n in range(101)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Apr 03 2017
results.author: _Bernardo Boncompagni_, Feb 13 2007
ext: More terms from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Feb 20 2007
